Navigating the AI gold rush: Promise, power, and paradox

The AI industry is in a transformative phase akin to a digital gold rush, driven by explosive user adoption, capital infusion, and global ambition. With over 800 million users for ChatGPT alone, and AI CapEx across tech giants soaring to US$212 billion, the pace is not just historic, it's redefining the economics of innovation. Yet this meteoric rise is shadowed by systemic paradoxes.

Startups and incumbents alike are sprinting toward monetisation through subscriptions, APIs, and enterprise integration. However, the road to profitability remains uncertain. High burn rates and energy-intensive infrastructure threaten sustainability, and the very accessibility that fuels adoption could undermine the exclusivity needed for monetisation.

Geopolitics adds another layer of complexity. The intensifying US-China AI rivalry turns every algorithm into a strategic asset. Meanwhile, open-source models, though democratising, are destabilising proprietary moats.

The AI boom is no longer just a technological story; it is a convergence of capitalism, geopolitics, and societal transformation. As capabilities race ahead of governance and business models, the sector faces a crucial question: can it sustain this velocity without imploding under its own weight?

In this unfolding drama, innovation is the fuel, but foresight and regulation will determine whether the future is prosperous or perilous.

urn:contentItem:68FP-XKB1-JB24-N002-00000-00JPMorgan Sets Out Core Principles for Carbon Markets2023-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:03:58ZLexisNexisJPMorgan Sets Out Core Principles for Carbon MarketsRanamita Chakraborty, Regulation Asia

JPMorgan has come up with a set of principles to address the current lack of trust in some existing carbon credits.

JPMorgan Chase has released a new white paper highlighting the role of carbon markets in accelerating the transition to a low-carbon economy, and calling for carbon credits to be used as a supportive tool and not to replace efforts to avoid, reduce, and neutralise emissions.

The paper comes after IOSCO issued two consultation papers last year - the first offering recommendations for jurisdictions seeking to establish compliance carbon markets, and the second exploring attributes that can foster sound voluntary carbon markets.

The new paper offers a set of "carbon market principles" for assessing carbon credits and approaching the voluntary carbon market. JPMorgan has been actively engaged in procuring carbon credits since 2007, initially prioritising nature-based solutions and subsequently venturing into emerging carbon removal approaches.

The paper says the voluntary carbon market is not a "silver bullet" but an "important tool for enabling the low-carbon transition to occur at a pace and scale commensurate with the climate challenge".

The voluntary carbon market allows individuals and organizsations to trade carbon credits, which represent efforts to avoid, reduce, or remove greenhouse gases. In this market, project developers create and sell credits, while companies and intermediaries buy them to offset their emissions.

However, the market faces challenges such as a limited supply of high-quality credits and a lack of trust in some existing credits, according to the paper. JPMorgan has therefore come up with carbon market principles to guide its involvement in the market.

The principles are derived from a review of available literature, standards and guidance from leading organisations, internal deliberation and consultation with experts and stakeholders.

"Until there is convergence on a common set of standards and accountability mechanisms, organisations must largely rely on their own processes for navigating the voluntary market to meet their business and sustainability goals," the paper says.

The principles for evaluating the quality and credibility of carbon credits are:

Real. All emission reductions and removals, and the project activities from which they are generated, should be proven to have genuinely taken place.

Measurable. All emission reductions and removals should be quantifiable, using recognised measurement tools against a credible emissions baseline.

Additional. The project would not have been undertaken without the carbon credit revenue, and the impact would not have been realised if the project had not been carried out.

Unique & Traceable. No more than one carbon credit may be associated with a single emission reduction or removal as one (1) metric ton of carbon dioxide equivalent.

Independently Verified. The purchased credit should be certified by a recognised GHG crediting programme or verified by an independent third party to reduce the risk of low-quality credits.

Leakage Avoidance. Projects should not create carbon reductions in one location by displacing the high-emitting activity to another location.

Durability/Permanence. Carbon credits should represent durable sequestration of carbon from the atmosphere.

Climate Equity. Project should support and elevate frontline, indigenous or other marginalised communities, where feasible.

Other considerations for carbon credits include strong co-benefits, cost, scalability potential and innovation, the paper says.

"As one of the world's largest financial institutions, we have the opportunity to help define and implement best practices and influence the further development of an effective voluntary market," JPMorgan said, adding that the paper articulates its perspective as well as aligns its approach and principles across the firm.

Moving forward, JPM plans to continue working to refine and incorporate these principles across relevant business activities. It aims to support more unified global standards and improvements in market infrastructure as well as focus on better evaluating the impact and durability of nature-based removal projects.

urn:contentItem:66VM-FGN1-JCF2-83NW-00000-00Inequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara director2022-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:03:58ZLexisNexisGOVERNMENT & ECONOMYGlobal EnterpriseInequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara director

[SHARM EL-SHEIK, EGYPT] Advanced economies, particularly those in the European Union, are trying to impose their own decarbonisation pathways onto emerging markets in South-east Asia without working together with the less developed countries, said Madelena Mohamed, director of Bank Negara Malaysia's sustainability unit.One such example is the proposed carbon border adjustment mechanism, which seeks to propose tariffs on EU imports based on their emissions content - a measure that would hit small and medium-sized enterprises from emerging markets the hardest, Madelena told The Business Times on the sidelines of the 27th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP27)."Because they want to move, they want everybody to move at the same pace as theirs, so that nobody will actually be a drag to them," she said. "Instead of working together, helping others to actually move. So, this is what we call climate equity. We don't see that there is actually climate equity, because, you know, the advanced economies are dictating."Demands for high-income nations to do more to help developing countries combat climate change has always been a point of contention at the annual climate conference, with tensions intensified this year as negotiations on loss and damage funding - which refers to the destructive impacts of climate change that cannot be avoided by either mitigation or adaptation - was officially included in the agenda.While Madelena did not specifically comment on loss and damage financing, she said that what is needed is capital investments and technology transfer.

"The advanced economies are talking about commitments and so forth," she said. "I think for several COPs they have actually been talking about that. But I think, in reality, is that really happening? Is it really happening at the scale and at the pace It should be? Because we don't think it is."But Sean Kidney, chief executive officer of the sustainable finance advocacy group Climate Bonds Initiative, said that companies need to sprint ahead in their energy transition, and not see it as a "gentle run" given that it has entered the race late. He also said that the idea of 'just transition' - an approach advocated by top officials in the region to ensure that the negative consequences of energy transition on society are mitigated - should not be used as an excuse to slow down."We've got to enable and support companies, not get them to slow down. Now a lot of the just transition is 'Hang on, take it easy, we're gonna lose a lot of workers.' That is the bad way. That is the problem. Rather, go full steam ahead. But make sure you've got someone behind you to pick up the people who have been left behind," he said. Kidney said that role should be mainly left to governments to make sure they get trained and find new work, such as in the case of Sweden."The reason we're talking about special just-transition schemes is the failure of the state to support many places," he added. When asked about whether there is fairness in expecting emerging economies to move at the same pace as advanced economies, Kidney said: "I mean, there's a lot of unfairness going on in the world, as if that's ever changed anything". "By all means go red in the face and talk about unfairness. But let's just get real about managing our world... Guilt hasn't been motivating change in the last 20 years, don't think it's going to make any difference now," he said. What Asean economies need to do, in its decarbonisation journey, is to push for cheap capital, he added. "We're not going to get handouts, we're not going to get grants. We're not going to get justice."However, Madelena argued that most of the financing for emerging markets in Asean do not come cheap, even those offered by multilateral development banks. "They may, actually for instance, give you concessional rates, but it is actually in foreign currency. So then you have to take the foreign exchange risk. So at the end of the day, you know, all in, it is expensive," she added.Notwithstanding the hurdles, central banks in Asean are pressing on with their efforts to push forward decarbonisation in the region, Madalena said.An Asean task force co-chaired by Madelena and comprising central banks in the region, has put together a report on the roles of central banks in the region in mitigating climate risks in November 2020, and they are in the midst of implementing these recommendations, though they are non-binding. Some of these recommendations include setting up an Asean green map, building up capacity and awareness on climate change, as well as establishing an Asean taxonomy. The first version of the Asean taxonomy, which provides definitions of what can be considered green for the purpose of obtaining sustainable finance, was published in Nov 2021. The Asean Taxonomy Board is currently in the midst of preparing the second version. "I think whatever that is being worked on now, there's a need for us to give time for that to happen, to take place," Madalena said. "So the key thing is, you have the recommendations, but now it's really to implement it."

Madelena Mohamed, director of Bank Negara Malaysia's sustainability unit, at the Malaysia pavilion at the COP27 climate summit.

urn:contentItem:66VM-FGN1-JCF2-83R2-00000-00Inequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara director2022-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:03:58ZLexisNexisTHE BUSINESS OF ESGInequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara directorBY JANICE LIM, Inequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara director

Sharm El-Sheik, Egypt

ADVANCED economies, particularly those in the European Union, are trying to impose their own decarbonisation pathways onto emerging markets in South-east Asia without working together with the less developed countries, said Madelena Mohamed, director of Bank Negara Malaysia's sustainability unit.

One such example is the proposed carbon border adjustment mechanism, which seeks to propose tariffs on EU imports based on their emissions content -- a measure that would hit small and medium-sized enterprises from emerging markets the hardest, Madelena told The Business Times on the sidelines of the 27th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP27).

"Because they want to move, they want everybody to move at the same pace as theirs, so that nobody will actually be a drag to them," she said. "Instead of working together, helping others to actually move. So, this is what we call climate equity. We don't see that there is actually climate equity, because, you know, the advanced economies are dictating."

Demands for high-income nations to do more to help developing countries combat climate change has always been a point of contention at the annual climate conference, with tensions intensified this year as negotiations on loss and damage funding -- which refers to the destructive impacts of climate change that cannot be avoided by either mitigation or adaptation -- was officially included in the agenda.

While Madelena did not specifically comment on loss and damage financing, she said that what is needed is capital investments and technology transfer.

"The advanced economies are talking about commitments and so forth," she said. "I think for several COPs they have actually been talking about that. But I think, in reality, is that really happening? Is it really happening at the scale and at the pace It should be? Because we don't think it is."

But Sean Kidney, chief executive officer of the sustainable finance advocacy group Climate Bonds Initiative, said that companies need to sprint ahead in their energy transition, and not see it as a "gentle run" given that it has entered the race late.

He also said that the idea of 'just transition' -- an approach advocated by top officials in the region to ensure that the negative consequences of energy transition on society are mitigated -- should not be used as an excuse to slow down.

"We've got to enable and support companies, not get them to slow down. Now a lot of the just transition is 'Hang on, take it easy, we're gonna lose a lot of workers.' That is the bad way. That is the problem. Rather, go full steam ahead. But make sure you've got someone behind you to pick up the people who have been left behind," he said.

Kidney said that role should be mainly left to governments to make sure they get trained and find new work, such as in the case of Sweden. "The reason we're talking about special just-transition schemes is the failure of the state to support many places," he added.

When asked about whether there is fairness in expecting emerging economies to move at the same pace as advanced economies, Kidney said: "I mean, there's a lot of unfairness going on in the world, as if that's ever changed anything".

"By all means go red in the face and talk about unfairness. But let's just get real about managing our world ... Guilt hasn't been motivating change in the last 20 years, don't think it's going to make any difference now," he said.

What Asean economies need to do, in its decarbonisation journey, is to push for cheap capital, he added. "We're not going to get handouts, we're not going to get grants. We're not going to get justice."

However, Madelena argued that most of the financing for emerging markets in Asean do not come cheap, even those offered by multilateral development banks.

"They may, actually for instance, give you concessional rates, but it is actually in foreign currency. So then you have to take the foreign exchange risk. So at the end of the day, you know, all in, it is expensive," she added.

Notwithstanding the hurdles, central banks in Asean are pressing on with their efforts to push forward decarbonisation in the region, Madalena said.

An Asean task force co-chaired by Madelena and comprising central banks in the region, has put together a report on the roles of central banks in the region in mitigating climate risks in November 2020, and they are in the midst of implementing these recommendations, though they are non-binding.

Some of these recommendations include setting up an Asean green map, building up capacity and awareness on climate change, as well as establishing an Asean taxonomy.

The first version of the Asean taxonomy, which provides definitions of what can be considered green for the purpose of obtaining sustainable finance, was published in Nov 2021.

The Asean Taxonomy Board is currently in the midst of preparing the second version.

"I think whatever that is being worked on now, there's a need for us to give time for that to happen, to take place," Madalena said. "So the key thing is, you have the recommendations, but now it's really to implement it."

urn:contentItem:6D0N-G3C1-DY39-81WH-00000-00工教院三年内将耗资1000万元在校园安装太阳能板2024-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:03:58ZLexisNexis新加坡头版工教院三年内将耗资1000万元在校园安装太阳能板廖慧婷

本地大专院校采取各种措施推进可持续发展，其中工艺教育学院三年内将耗资1000万元，在校园内安装太阳能板等节省能源，协助旗下学院达到超低能耗目标。

来自新加坡管理大学、新加坡理工学院，以及新加坡工艺教育局的领导星期二（9月17日）出席第二届新加坡管理大学永续发展论坛时，在小组讨论会上谈到个别高等教育学府在建立气候韧性方面的计划。

工艺教育局总裁卢巧玉透露，从去年起到明年，当局三年内将耗资1000万元，在校园内优化有关设备以及安装更多太阳能板等，以节省两成能源。"这两成节省的电力，每年可省下约220万元的电费。五年下来，我们便可以回收成本。"

她也说，目前三所工艺教育学院属于低能耗，其中一所达到超低能耗标准，这些投资将协助另两所工教院达到超低能耗的目标。此外，工教院也打算在明年推出有关电网管理的新课程。

新加坡理工学院院长兼总裁苏卫华则重申，为支持2030年新加坡绿色发展蓝图，新加坡理工学院设下在2030年前减排60%的愿景，并致力于在2045年之前达到净零排放。

马炎庆：迈向可持续发展 政府业界教育学府须合作

永续发展与环境部兼交通部高级政务次长马炎庆在论坛上致辞时指出，全球暖化对新加坡可能带来的危害，以及我国在应对海平面上升、加强粮食安全以及减少碳排放方面的努力。

"在我国持续迈向可持续发展的过程中，政府、业界和高等教育学府之间的合作，将是实现我们目标的关键。"

例如，由新大、新加坡国立大学等学术和研究机构携手进行的"新加坡降温研究项目2.0"，旨在发展可应对我国城市热化的方案。马炎庆说："这些倡议展示了高等教育学府在促进研究与创新、孵化创意，并将它们转化为实际解决方案来应对我们所面对的复杂挑战方面，发挥不可或缺的作用。"

在小组讨论谈到高等教育学府可以如何合作时，新大行政事务高级总监林文威认为，我国推出的绿色发展蓝图拥有很好的整体框架，但个别学府也可以发挥所长，带来不同观点与合作伙伴，联合为该蓝图做出贡献。

另一方面，新大综合学科学院去年推出学士课程延期申报制度，并让学生自行决定专属主修课程，本学年迎来首批决定个人专属主修的44名学生。

其中一人是对气候变化课题深感兴趣而决定主修气候公平治理（Climate Equity）的大二生郑靖颐（20岁）。

"我希望毕业后能从事有关拟定政策方面的工作，或继续深造研究气候变化相关课题，希望为环境带来一些贡献。"
